“Going to the police station right now.”

Interpol said in a statement: “There is not, and never has been, a Red Notice for Mr. Bill Browder.”

This is the arrest warrant pic.twitter.com/Cr1Sf4vS4a — Bill Browder (@Billbrowder) May 30, 2018

Russia has tried on several occasions to issue warrants for Browder in the past to no avail.

ROBIN VAN LONKHUIJSEN via Getty Images CEO of Hermitage Capital Management Bill Browder, a former Moscow financier turned anti-Kremlin activist, walks in the House of Representatives in The Hague on May 23, 2018.
He’s on the country’s blacklist for exposing a $230 million Kremlin tax fraud scam involving Hermitage Capital Management, the company he started in Moscow in the 1990s.
Browder successfully lobbied Congress to pass the Magnitsky Act in 2012, which imposes sanctions on Russian individuals believed to be implicated in Magnitsky’s murder.
William Browder, CEO of Hermitage Capital and anti-Kremlin activist, said he was arrested on fraud charges in Madrid on Wednesday on a Russian Interpol warrant.
Browder turned to activism once Sergei Magnitsky, the lawyer who worked with him to uncover the corruption scandal, was killed in a Russian prison.
Several countries including Canada and the UK have since followed suit, introducing legislation for their own Magnitsky Acts.
He was later released, he added, after Interpol advised Spanish authorities not to honor Russia’s request for the arrest.
“Urgent: Just was arrested by Spanish police in Madrid on a Russian Interpol arrest warrant,” he tweeted initially.
They won’t tell me which station pic.twitter.com/Xwj27xC7Zd — Bill Browder (@Billbrowder) May 30, 2018
In the back of the Spanish police car going to the station on the Russian arrest warrant.
